data.name: Triangulate a konvex polygon
data.description: A convex polygon is a polygon, in which all internal angles are less than or equal to 180°. Examples of convex polygons are rectangle, pentagon, hexagon, heptagon etc. Depending on the number of vertices, there are multiple ways to triangulate such a polygon with diagonals. Visualization: Assume that this is a rectangle: ``` __ | | | | ¯¯ ``` then the possible triangulations are: ``` __ __ |\ | | /| | \| |/ | ¯¯ ¯¯ ``` In this Kata, you will implement a function ```possible_triangulations(n)``` that returns the number of possible triangulations of a convex polygon with n vertices. If the number of vertices is less than 4, return 'Not a valid polygon'. Examples: For n=2, ```possible_triangulations(2)``` returns 2, as there are two ways to triangulate a rectangle. For n=5, ```possible_triangulations(5)``` returns 5 Notes/hints: - The diagonals go from one vertex to any other and are not intersecting. - If you have problems solving this mathematical problem: this calculation is closely related to Catalan numbers. - As the solution will most likely be computationally complex, I limit the test cases to 1000 vertices.
